importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's publication, when the public was informed of renewed pressure on Curtis Sliwa to drop out of the NYC mayoral race due to pressure from John Catsimatidis and other Republican figures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline shows the rapid escalation of political pressure on Curtis Sliwa, culminating in direct appeals from Catsimatidis and public rebuttals from Sliwa and Zohran Mamdani over the past 48 hours.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is facing pressure to withdraw from the race from his boss, John Catsimatidis.

John Catsimatidis, a Republican supermarket magnate and longtime New Yorker, publicly urged Sliwa to drop out, arguing that Sliwa should prioritize New York City's interests over his personal campaign.
Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is actively trying to unite Republican opposition against Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani by pushing Sliwa out of the race.

Sliwa has rejected the pressure, asserting that voters — not billionaire donors or political allies — should determine the city’s future and emphasizing his representation of blue-collar working-class New Yorkers.
Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime,' mocking his affinity for cats and animal rescues, indicating broader Republican skepticism of Sliwa’s candidacy.

Zohran Mamdani has dismissed claims of coordination with Sliwa, noting their shared opposition to billionaire influence in city politics and urging both candidates to focus on their own messaging to voters.
Sliwa is polling third in the mayoral race, behind Cuomo and Mamdani, and has gained attention following a strong performance in a recent debate.
Sliwa's background includes founding the Guardian Angels, and he has been a perennial mayoral candidate since 2021 without holding office.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is facing mounting pressure to withdraw from the race, including direct appeals from his boss John Catsimatidis and efforts by former Governor Andrew Cuomo to consolidate Republican opposition against Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani. While Catsimatidis and others argue that Sliwa should prioritize the city’s interests, Sliwa has defended his candidacy, rejecting claims that he is a weak or unviable option and emphasizing his representation of working-class voters. The situation has drawn criticism from both sides, with Trump mocking Sliwa's image and Cuomo dismissing him as a 'shock jock,' while Mamdani and Sliwa have formed a rare alliance in opposing billionaire influence in politics. Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels, remains a third-place contender in the race and has gained renewed attention after a strong debate performance, asserting that voters, not donors, should decide the city’s future.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
